name: URL bar background based on site security
description: A compliment to the Web of Trust browser interface enhancements style, a collaborative work created and fussed about by the hands of me, Grom, LouCypher and Sonny. Tested and verified working as a user would expect, I proudly present this work. None of this stuff was particularly easy for me to understand or figure out, but with the help of many people, I've managed to come up with this. Show them some appreciation and check out their content.
additional_info: Information When you visit any website with HTTPS, be it a website with a verified identity, secured connection or secure site with non-secure content, the URL bar will modify itself in accordance with what kind of website you're on. All, or if not, most extensions are compatible with this style. Mind the color of the stripes in the bar: Green: Secure website with extended validation (like addons.mozilla.org) Blue: Secure website with standard validation (like https://www.google.com) Orange: Secure websites with non-secured content, or rather, websites with mixed content. Mixed content uses a more cautionary color, because mixed content websites -- Those with insecure HTTP content in an HTTPS space can become compromised by malicious hackers and risk revealing your identity and sensitive details to whoever is maliciously utilizing this information. Since not everyone will know at-a-glance the mixed content icon, or care to see it, blasting this information in your face with a splash of color is a sure-fire way to know if you're in a space where your personal information can become compromised. The images in the style are encoded in Base64. Don't fret, you can remove them rather easily. If the pattern is too busy, or if the pattern feels unwarranted, let me know in a discussion and I'll gladly modify it to solid colors. Don't want anyone getting headaches or seizures from using this! Change log 09/27/13 I decided to not rremove the background from the identity box, since there are other styles that tamper with the appearance of it already. It is outside the scope of this style to do such a thing, and I don't want something to break because of my apparent ignorance of this. 09/28/13 TSS suggested a modification I'll keep inactive for the time being. If you REALLY don't want Status-4-Evar or GlassMyFox, enable the fix by removing lines specified in the code. On this same day, Grom told me why adding z-index: 1 !important; was important, and I'm sorry for all the fuss I caused. I'm done, it works bug-free, it works error-free, everything is as it should be.
